creator: s.i.warhurst@rl.ac.uk
text:
I have a directory on a web server:
http://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/files/sw-test

In the .htaccess file for that directory the following lines appear:

AddDescription "This is a test document" test.doc
AddDescription "This is a file test" file-test.doc

Yet, as you can see, when Apache does a directory listing, the description it 
shows for file-test.doc is the one for test.doc.

The reason you're getting the same description for both files is that
the filename on the AddDescription is treated as a partial filename, and
test.doc is a substring of both filenames, and the description for
test.doc happens to be found before the description for file-test.doc.
(See the doc at
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/mod/mod_autoindex.html#adddescription.)

You could reverse the order of your AddDescription entries and you should
get the right output (though I don't think that is guaranteed to work forever).

I tried to find a guaranteed way to always get the right description, but
I haven't had luck yet.  (Specifying a full filename instead of simply
"test.doc" has some unexpected behavior that I'm still investigating.)
creator: trawick@apache.org

text: Allowing backslash escaping would do the trick?
creator: davi@apache.org

text:
In r894306 I've added an additional paragraph of explanation that clarifies what's going on here. If you'll reorder your AddDescription directives, the problem goes away. It's first-match.

In short, it appears to be working as designed, and, as of r894306, as documented.
